articles.author: Abolfazl Soltani
articles.description:
We see two fields in this object that are part of the prototype of JavaScript objects.
If youâ€™re a frontend developer, or have even written JavaScript once, youâ€™ve probably seen [object Object] appear in your output or console logs.
What is this mysterious string? Why do we see it instead of a useful string representation of our object? ðŸ¤”
Despite appearances, [object Object] is not an array or some special string. Itâ€™s the default string representation of a plain JavaScript object.
Hereâ€™s why:
JavaScriptâ€™s type system works on values, not variables. When you try to convert an object to a string or number (called type coercion), JavaScript internally uses the ToPrimitive algorithm to figure out how to do this.
ToPrimitive tries to convert objects by calling two special methods on them:
1. â€¦
articles.title: [ object Object ]

articles.author: Tahsin Abrar
articles.description:
If you've been working with Laravel and MySQL for a while, you've probably hit some common performance pitfallsâ€”like slow queries, N+1 problems, and inefficient use of relationships.
Today, let's walk through some real-world strategies to optimize your Laravel app using:
Count optimizations in Eloquent
Avoiding the dreaded N+1 problem with withCount

Structuring withCount queries
Using polymorphic relationships effectively
Letâ€™s dive in. ðŸŠâ€â™‚ï¸
Many Laravel developers tend to do this:
$post = Post::find(1);
$commentCount = $post->comments()->count();

While this works fine, if you're doing it inside a loop or multiple times, it executes a separate SQL query each time, which adds up quickly. Imagine a page with 10 postsâ€”yep, thatâ€™s 11 queries: one for posts and one per postâ€™s comments.
Betteâ€¦
articles.title: Laravel Performance Tips: Count Optimization, Avoiding N+1, and Polymorphic Relationships

articles.author: Eastspire
articles.description:
As a junior computer science student, I was working on a campus second-hand trading platform project last semester when I stumbled upon the Hyperlane Rust HTTP framework. I was in a dilemma about choosing a frameworkâ€” it needed to be powerful enough to handle the peak trading at the end of the semester, and its syntax had to be simple so that I, as a Rust newbie, could get up to speed quickly. To my pleasant surprise, Hyperlane exceeded all my expectations. Today, I want to share my experience with this amazing framework!
When I first started writing route functions, I was amazed by Hyperlaneâ€™s Context (or ctx for short). I remember the first time I wanted to get the request method. In traditional Rust HTTP frameworks, I would have to write:
let method = ctx.get_request().await.get_method(â€¦
articles.title: My Experience with Hyperlane: A Rust Newbieâ€™s Journey in Developing a Campus API

articles.author: Eastspire
articles.description:
As a junior majoring in computer science, I was introduced to the Hyperlane framework while working on a Web service project. This high-performance Rust HTTP framework completely changed my perception of Web development. Below is my true experience of learning and applying Hyperlane.
When I first started using Hyperlane, I was pleasantly surprised by its clean Context (ctx) abstraction. Previously, in other frameworks, I had to write verbose calls like:
let method = ctx.get_request().await.get_method();

Now, itâ€™s as simple as one line of code:
let method = ctx.get_request_method().await;

This design significantly enhances the readability of my code, especially when dealing with complex business logic, eliminating the need for nested method calls.
When implementing RESTful APIs, Hyperlaneâ€¦
articles.title: From Getting Started to Performance Optimization.

articles.author: Coder
articles.description:
Git Branching Strategies: A Deep Dive into Rebasing vs. Merging â€“ When to Use What
Git, as a powerful version control system, offers various strategies for integrating changes from different branches back into a shared codebase. Among the most common and often debated methods are merging and rebasing. Both achieve the goal of combining work, but they do so in fundamentally different ways, leading to distinct commit histories and implications for team collaboration. Understanding these differences is crucial for maintaining a clean, comprehensible project history and fostering efficient development workflows.
Merging is Git's default way of integrating changes. When you merge one branch into another, Git creates a new commitâ€”the merge commitâ€”that has two parent commits: the last commit of tâ€¦
articles.title: Git Branching Strategies: A Deep Dive into Rebasing vs. Merging â€“ When to Use What

Curhat Ngoding: Dari Kopi Sampai Deadline, Inilah Realita Jadi Software Engineer!


Jadi Software Engineer itu kayak roller coaster, bro! Ada kalanya kita ngerasa jadi superhero yang bisa nyelesein masalah rumit dalam semalam, tapi ada juga momen-momen yang bikin pengen nangis di pojokan sambil meluk guling. Nah, di artikel ini, gua mau curhat tentang suka duka jadi Software Engineer, mulai dari ritual ngopi yang sakral sampe ngadepin deadline yang bikin rambut rontok.
Kopi itu udah kayak pacar kedua buat para programmer. Serius deh! Gak percaya? Coba aja liat meja kerja temen-temen lu, pasti ada gelas kopi di sana. Kopi bukan cuma sekadar minuman, tapi udah jadi bagian dari workflow. Gua sendiri gak bisa bayangin gimana caranya ngoding tanpa kopi. Rasanya kayak ada yang kurang gitu. Bahkaâ€¦
articles.title: Curhat Ngoding: Dari Kopi Sampai Deadline, Inilah Realita Jadi Software Engineer!

articles.author: Ryan Adam
articles.description:
Have you ever launched a website and immediately regretted it?
https://www.codigo.co) is worth a visit.) But more importantly, they asked the right questions. Not just â€œwhat pages do you want?â€ but â€œwhat do your users need to do on this site?â€ and â€œhow does your business actually work?â€
It wasnâ€™t just about building a siteâ€”it was about building the right site.
Their team handled everything in-house: designers, front-end and back-end developers, and even testing. I could hop on a call and talk to the people writing the code. That level of transparency? Priceless.
The site they built for us didnâ€™t just look amazingâ€”it actually worked. And since launch, weâ€™ve had better conversions, faster load times, and (shocker) fewer complaints from customers.
So yeah. If youâ€™re thinking of building a web app or custom site and donâ€™t want to end up in the DIY agency horror story I started with, do yourself a favor and check out Codigo.
They get it.
articles.title: What I Learned the Hard Way About Hiring a Web Development Agency

When I first started using Hyperlane, I was pleasantly surprised by its clean Context (ctx) abstraction. Previously, in other frameworks, I had to write verbose calls like:
let method = ctx.get_request().await.get_method();

Now, itâ€™s as simple as one line of code:
let method = ctx.get_request_method().await;

This design significantly enhances the readability of my code, especially when dealing with complex business logic, eliminating the need for nested method calls.
When implementing RESTful APIs, Hyperlaneâ€¦

articles.author: MailSlurp
articles.description:
Secure application are often a complex process involving multiple factors of authentication. Many developers use services like Auth0, Firebase and Azure AD/Entra to build user login and sign up flows that connect applications to enterprise IdPs using MFA and 2FA flows. These methods often involve receiving verification codes and time-based one-time passwords (TOTP) to verify accounts.
Hint: TOTP stands for time-based one-time password. You might have used TOTP with Google Authenticator or Duo on a mobile device.

With strict compliance and regulatory requirements testing these apps end-to-end is crucial. This requires special QA techniques and disposable authenticator devices which we will demonstrate in this post. For this example we will use Selenium and Java but the methods for testing â€¦
articles.title: Testing OTP codes in Selenium with dummy authenticators
